Peter, a fitness function can certainly be embedded into the behavior
chara=
cterization.  At the extreme, the fitness function can be the
entire behavi=
or characterization (which means we try to get all
possible fitness scores,=
 which is similar to Hutter's
fitness-uniform-selection method).  Our preli=
minary experiments
suggest that if you only use the fitness function as the=
 behavior
characterization then that does not work as well as a more robust=

behavior characterization.  Yet combinations of behavioral and fitness
inf=
ormation may be useful and are an interesting subject for research.

Nature=
 has a sort of "fitness function" in the sense that everyone
must physicall=
y reproduce to maintain a lineage.  Yet this fitness
function does not meas=
ure progress towards any particular goal, so it
is different than the objec=
tive-based fitness used most often in EC,
where we measure progress to a go=
al.  The one in nature is more of a
"threshold condition" for being allowed=
 to continue a lineage.  It
might be interesting to impose something like t=
hat on a novelty search
too, in combination with the novelty metric

ken

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote=
:
>
> It is possble to keep only the recent behaviors (not the whole 
> his=
tory). I believe this is apropriate since when you reach that 
> point when=
 comparing to the archive becomes very slow, the search 
> would be far awa=
y from the initial behaviors anyway and the 
> probability of going backwar=
ds therefore should be minimal, unless 
> there is simplification (pruning)=
 of the genomes. 
> One thing to ask is, is it possible to incorporate a ki=
nd of 
> objective function into the behavior characterization, but not tak=
ing 
> that fitness score into consideration when individuals are selected?=
 
> The search should then focus on getting different fitnesses every 
> ti=
me, no matter high or low. 
> 
> Peter

hould require (sqrt(100.000))

y more tests indicates that the path space for NEAT is fairly

stronomical.  Yet

re was no performance hit

ical space is more expensive than

ould simply increase the

  Those are still both

om 400 to

a great factor.

eadily and at one point the test of whether the
